RE: re : Re: [junit] Embedding multiple Tests into a loop...For what its
worth, if you run your JUnit tests under Test Mentor, the default behavior
for Test Mentor's version of the assert(...) family is to log the result and
continue. Again, the JUnit add-on for Test Mentor - Java Edition will be
available for prerelease within the next couple of weeks and may be
requested at http://www.silvermark.com/evaluators/5.3junit_releaseinfo.html
if that sort of thing is interesting.



^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Mike Silverstein, Lead Architect        voice:  (919) 858-8300 x29
SilverMark, Inc.                        fax:    (919) 858-8308

Suite 510, Raleigh, NC 27606            toll free: (888) 588-0668
http://www.silvermark.com               msilverstein@...

  -----Original Message-----
  From: Herrick, Chuck [mailto:chuck.herrick@...]
  Sent: Monday, March 12, 2001 10:29 AM
  To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
  Subject: RE: re : Re: [junit] Embedding multiple Tests into a loop...


  I don't think your approach is foolish. I think JUnit ought to be smart
enough to allow an option to continue-on-failure.

    -----Original Message-----
    From:   tsmets@... [SMTP:tsmets@...]
    Sent:   Monday, March 12, 2001 9:19 AM
    To:     joi@...; junit@yahoogroups.com
    Subject:        re : Re: [junit] Embedding multiple Tests into a loop...



    Sounds the best option
    I'm just not acquainted to making suite & old FORTRAN taught me to use
vector or arrays like no other :-))
    Hence my foolish approach
    Tx,

    Thomas,



    <snip>
    There was a thread with a similar theme a few weeks ago.  I think its
    conclusion was that you should extend TestCase to accept a single
filename
    and run a single test object per filename.  Create a suite object
    which accepts the String Array and loops creating tests instead
    of the Test looping within itself.
    </snip>


    To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
    junit-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
